newsitem.title: UK: Clarke says Britain could still be first in EMU.
newsitem.headline: Clarke says Britain could still be first in EMU.

text.p: Britain could still be in the first group of countries to join a single European currency, the UK's Chancellor of the Exchequer Kenneth Clarke said.

"The cabinet has not ruled out joining in the first wave," Clarke told an interview with Wednesday's Financial Times newspaper, downplaying recent speculation that there had been a change of government policy toward the single currency.

Clarke reiterated the UK government's view that it is unlikely European Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) will start on time. But he said, "The chances are it (EMU) will start in the next parliament."
Prime Minister John Major is scheduled to call a general election by May.
"There can't be anyone who thinks I'm going to fight a Euro-sceptic election campaign," said Clarke, who is widely seen a pro-European within the cabinet.
On the domestic front, Clarke said there was evidence the economy was strengthening but there was no sign of an 1980s- style boom.
"I think everything shows a strengthening recovery, not out of hand, not showing symptoms of a boom and not building up inflationary pressures," he said.
Clarke, who recently cited the strength of the pound as a key reason for keeping interest rates on hold, said he was under no pressure to raise rates again before the election.
The Chancellor pointed out that when the UK was in the European exchange rate mechanism just five years ago, the pound was the "be-all-and-end-all" of the fight against inflation.
"It must be nonsense to assert that such a dramatic strengthening of the exchange rate has no anti-inflation effect," Clarke said.
Sterling has risen up to 6.6 percent against a trade- weighted basket of currencies since October, gaining as much as 14.4 percent against the German mark during that period.
The FT said the Chancellor criticised the Bank of England for paying too much attention to financial futures markets in saying interest rates would have to rise.
"I think in a way that we have have got a counter-inflation culture across to the general public better than to some of the people in the City," Clarke said.
Last week Bank of England governor Eddie George called for a "modest pre-emptive" rate rise.
UK base lending rates are currently 6.0 percent and were last raised by a quarter of a percentage point on October 30.
